elements.content: We present a tight-binding model that allows a quantitative fitting of the ab initio band structure, near the Fermi energy, of several 2D metal–organic and covalent–organic honeycomb-like frameworks. The model is based on the kagome–honeycomb lattice, defined as the superposition of the named lattices. The full spectrum of the model Hamiltonian is analytically solvable in the case of one orbital per site and nearest-neighbor hopping, and at selected points of the Brillouin zone for hopping up to second neighbors. With proper choices of parameters and band occupation, the model describes five types of electronic structure within this class of materials. All five types are obtained in explicit fittings of the model to first-principles calculations of 2D frameworks. The model also permits the identification of crystallographic point group broken symmetries that lead to band gap openings in Cu3(HITP)2. Spin–orbit effects are also investigated in model and first-principles calculations of Ni3C12S12.

elements.content: Covalent organic frameworks (COFs) and metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) constitute a class of synthetic materials obtained through the ordered polymerization of organic monomers into three-dimensional or two-dimensional crystalline frameworks that present nanometric-sized pores. In the case of COFs, the frameworks are linked by covalent bonds between the monomers and, in the case of MOFs, by metallic atoms as well. Recent experimental works have shown interesting phenomena in electron transport properties of MOFs, such as strong dependence of the conductivity on the presence of guest molecules at the MOF nanopores, on the metal-atom linker, and on oxidation states. Effects like these have led to the proposal and development of MOF-based electronic and optoelectronic devices. Recent theoretical works have also predicted interesting electronic properties in two-dimensional MOFs and COFs with honeycomb-like geometries, such as half-metallicity and topological edge states. The electronic bands of those frameworks have been shown to present both the characteristic Dirac points of Wallace’s model for the honeycomb lattice and the flat band characteristic of the kagome lattice.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Covalent organic frameworks (COFs) and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) constitute a class of synthetic materials obtained through the ordered polymerization of organic monomers into three-dimensional or two-dimensional crystalline frameworks that present nanometric-sized pores. In the case of COFs, the frameworks are linked by covalent bonds between the monomers and, in the case of MOFs, by metallic atoms as well. Recent experimental works have shown interesting phenomena in electron transport properties of MOFs, such as strong dependence of the conductivity on the presence of guest molecules at the MOF nanopores, on the metal-atom linker, and on oxidation states. Effects like these have led to the proposal and development of MOF-based electronic and optoelectronic devices. Recent theoretical works have also predicted interesting electronic properties in two-dimensional MOFs and COFs with honeycomb-like geometries, such as half-metallicity and topological edge states. The electronic bands of those frameworks have been shown to present both the characteristic Dirac points of Wallace's model for the honeycomb lattice and the flat band characteristic of the kagome lattice.

elements.content: In the present work, we present a tight-binding model that, together with first-principles calculations, allows for a quantitative fitting of the electronic structure of several 2D honeycomb metal–organic and covalent–organic frameworks near the Fermi energy. The model is based on the kagome–honeycomb (KH) lattice, defined as the superposition of the kagome and the honeycomb lattices, as shown in . The five-band model is analytically solvable in the case of one orbital per site and nearest-neighbor hopping. In the case of first- and second-neighbor hopping, analytical solutions are also obtained at selected k points. With proper choices of parameters and band occupation, the model describes the five basic types of electronic structure within this class of materials: metallic, graphene-like, gapped graphene, and semiconductor with a flat band degenerate with either of the band edges. Neither Wallace’s model for the honeycomb lattice nor the three-band kagome lattice model can describe all these types of electronic structure due to the absence of band gaps. Here, the KH lattice model is explicitly fitted to first-principles calculations of several examples of 2D honeycomb frameworks. Specifically, we consider the following: single layers of Cu3(HITP)2, which are obtained experimentally in bulk and thin film forms and that depict electronic conduction; single layers of Ni3C12S12, which were successfully synthesized on HOPG substrates; and several 2D COFs proposed by Jean-Joseph et al. The KH lattice model also allows the investigation of effects resulting from the symmetry breaking between the two honeycomb sites and between the three kagome sites. We show that both types of symmetry breaking occur in the investigated MOFs and COFs. In contrast, Wallace’s model can only describe the first type of symmetry breaking, and the kagome lattice model can only describe the second one. Finally, we show that the inclusion of spin–orbit coupling terms in the KH lattice model allows for a quantitative description of the spin–orbit coupling induced band gaps of Ni3C12S12, including the asymmetry between these gaps in the valence and in the conduction bands.

elements.content: In the usual tight-binding methodology for periodic systems, single electron wave functions are expanded in terms of atomic orbitals centered at the atomic sites i of the crystal. Here we will adopt an effective tight-binding Hamiltonian methodology similar, for instance, to one previously used in the study of periodic lattices of Au nanoparticles. In that work, each nanoparticle was considered as a single pseudoatomic site, with a corresponding localized basis function. Here, we will consider the sites i of the kagome–honeycomb lattice shown in as the pseudoatomic sites. The Hamiltonian is given by H = ∑ i ε i c i † c i + ∑ i j t i j c i † c j where c i † and c i are creation and annihilation operators at the pseudoatomic site i. We will consider in this work hopping terms t ij up to second nearest neighbors only, which already correspond to large distances in the real atomic systems. We will show that this Hamiltonian allows for several analytical results, including the exact five-band spectrum in the case of nearest-neighbor hopping only. We will also show that the spectrum of the Hamiltonian can be well fitted to the five electronic bands nearest to the Fermi energy obtained from first-principles calculations of several frameworks. We will also show that the breaking of the nontranslational symmetry between the two honeycomb sites and those of the three kagome sites in the primitive unit cell leads to band gap openings that can be associated with the physical mechanisms of band gap opening in specific frameworks, including the single-layer Cu3(HITP)2. The effects of the inclusion of spin–orbit coupling terms in the model will be also investigated.

Here we will adopt an effective tight-binding Hamiltonian methodology similar, for instance, to one previously used in the study of periodic lattices of Au nanoparticles. In that work, each nanoparticle was considered as a single pseudoatomic site, with a corresponding localized basis function. Here, we will consider the sites i of the kagome-honeycomb lattice shown in  as the pseudoatomic sites. elements.content: Our first-principles methodology is based on the density functional theory (DFT) as implemented in the SIESTA code. We used the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) as parametrized in the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) for the exchange-correlation functional. The ionic core potentials were represented by norm-conserving scalar relativistic Troullier–Martins pseudopotentials in Kleinman–Bylander nonlocal form. The fineness of the real-space grid integration was defined by a energy cutoff of 400 Ry. For geometry optimization, the magnitude of the largest force acting on the atoms is set to be less than 0.01 eV/Å, and a vacuum layer of 20 Å is added so that the interlayer interactions are negligible. The Brillouin zones were sampled through the Monkhorst–Pack scheme using a 6 × 6 × 1 and 4 × 4 × 1 k-mesh for the 2D COFs and MOF, respectively. The accuracy of their band structures was guaranteed by a twice denser k-mesh.
elements.clean_text:
First-Principles Methodology

Our first-principles methodology is based on the density functional theory (DFT) as implemented in the SIESTA code. We used the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) as parametrized in the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) for the exchange-correlation functional. The ionic core potentials were represented by norm-conserving scalar relativistic Troullier-Martins pseudopotentials in Kleinman-Bylander nonlocal form. The fineness of the real-space grid integration was defined by a energy cutoff of 400 Ry. For geometry optimization, the magnitude of the largest force acting on the atoms is set to be less than 0.01 eV/Å, and a vacuum layer of 20 Å is added so that the interlayer interactions are negligible. The Brillouin zones were sampled through the Monkhorst-Pack scheme using a 6 × 6 × 1 and 4 × 4 × 1 k-mesh for the 2D COFs and MOF, respectively. The accuracy of their band structures was guaranteed by a twice denser k-mesh.

elements.content: Further calculations of the band structure, including spin–orbit coupling and hybrid exchange, were performed with the VASP code. The exchange-correlation potential was calculated in two alternative approaches. The first is the PBE GGA functional, described above. The second is the hybrid Heyd–Scuseria–Ernzerhof (HSE06) functional, which improves the description of the electronic band gap of semiconducting materials as compared to GGA. The electron–ion interaction is described by projector-augmented-wave (PAW) pseudopotentials. The Brillouin zone was sampled through the Monkhorst–Pack scheme using a 8 × 8 × 1 (3 × 3 × 1) k-mesh for the calculations of band structures using the PBE (HSE06) functional. For both functionals we employ a plane-wave energy cutoff of 300 eV.

elements.content: Let us first consider the explicit fitting of the tight-binding Hamiltonians H 0 and H 0 +V to the electronic structure of several COFs that were proposed by Jean-Joseph et al. and that were shown to present graphene-like bands and kagome-like flat bands. These COFs are formed through the linkage between conjugated polymers such as polythiophene (PTh) or polypyrene (PPyr) and atoms that are known to form strong covalent bonds like C, B, and N. The fitting of H 0 and H 0 + V to the band structures of the COFs PTh–L (L = C, N, and B) is shown in a–c and to the COF PPyr–C in d. a–d show that the analytical band structure within the nearest-neighbor hopping approximation, given by –, already provides a quantitative agreement with the first-principles results of these COFs for the three bands closest to the band gap region of the spectrum. The inclusion of second-neighbor hopping improves the fitting of the bands with the highest and lowest energies of the model, allowing for a quantitative description of the band structure near the upper and lower Dirac points, that is, at the graphene-like regions of the spectrum. We should also mention that the kagome–honeycomb tight-binding Hamiltonian provides a common description for the three types of electronic structure among the COFs of : graphene-like (PTh–C, PPyr–C), semiconductor with a flat band at the conduction band minimum (PTh–N), and semiconductor with a flat band at the valence band maximum (PTh–B). The sets of tight-binding parameters used to obtain these fittings within the second-neighbors hopping approximation are shown in .

elements.content: Let us now consider the symmetry breaking among the three kagome sites of the unit cell and the consequences on the electronic structure. As an example, we will consider a single layer of the recently synthesized MOF Cu3(HITP)2. The top view of the atomic structure of this MOF, obtained from first-principles, is shown in a. From that point of view the MOF appears as a symmetric kagome–honeycomb framework, with Cu atoms placed at the kagome sites and the organic moieties at the honeycomb sites. However, as previously obtained by Shuang Chen et al., the Cu atom forms tetrahedral bonds with the neighboring N atoms through sp3 hybridization, leading to a distorted (not in-plane) structure for single-layer Cu3(HITP)2. This distortion is shown in b and c with the inclusion of arrows that point from the lower nitrogen neighbors to the upper nitrogen neighbors of each Cu atom. The arrows in c show that the structure is not invariant under ±2π/3 rotations around the central H site (i.e., the center of the central triangular HITP molecule). Now, considering the Cu atoms of c labeled 1–3, one can also see that the structure is invariant with respect to ±π rotations around the vertical axis that passes through Cu 3. Therefore, Cu atoms 1 and 2 are equivalent through point-group operations, while Cu 3 is a distinct site. This can also be seen in the projected density of states (PDOS) at the Cu atoms presented in d, which shows that the PDOS at Cu atoms 1 and 2 are identical and that they are distinct from the PDOS of Cu 3. These broken-symmetry properties are consistent with XPS measurements on Cu3(HITP)2 samples that indicate the existence of two distinct Cu sites.

The figure clearly shows a manifold of five bands near the Fermi energy which is shown in an enlarged scale in f as a blue line, together with the results of the fitted tight-binding Hamiltonian with hopping up to second neighbors and with the above constraints on the ε K i and ε H i . The set of tight-binding parameters used to obtain this fitting within the second-neighbors hopping approximation is show in . f shows a very good agreement between first-principles and tight-binding results for this framework, both calculations showing the following: (i) the existence of dispersion in the previously flat band; (ii) the opening of a gap between that flat band and the conduction band above it at Γ; and (iii) the opening of gaps at both Dirac points at K. Features (ii) and (iii) are shown on a smaller energy scale in g. Given the agreement between model and first-principles, and given that the only modification in the model was setting a distinct value for ε K 3 , we are led to the conclusion that features (i)–(iii) are the result of the broken symmetry among the Cu sites.

elements.content: Spin–orbit coupling effects are expected to be more important in honeycomb-like MOFs than in the corresponding COFs due to the existence of (heavier) metal atoms in the structure. Previous theoretical works have indeed reported such effects in several honeycomb-like MOFs. We mention, in particular, the cases of the Ni3(HITP)2 and Ni3C12S12 MOFs. The band structures of those materials are very similar to each other, exhibiting kagome-like bands above the Fermi level. Upon inclusion of spin–orbit coupling, nontrivial band gaps open at the Dirac cones, leading to topological edge states similar to those predicted for graphene, but with much larger gap values due to the stronger spin–orbit coupling.
elements.clean_text:
Spin-Orbit Coupling Effects

Spin-orbit coupling effects are expected to be more important in honeycomb-like MOFs than in the corresponding COFs due to the existence of (heavier) metal atoms in the structure. Previous theoretical works have indeed reported such effects in several honeycomb-like MOFs. We mention, in particular, the cases of the Ni3(HITP)2  and Ni3C12S12  MOFs. The band structures of those materials are very similar to each other, exhibiting kagome-like bands above the Fermi level. Upon inclusion of spin-orbit coupling, nontrivial band gaps open at the Dirac cones, leading to topological edge states similar to those predicted for graphene, but with much larger gap values due to the stronger spin-orbit coupling.

elements.content: Here we will address the electronic structure of Ni3C12S12, a material that has been already synthesized experimentally as single layer, from both first-principles and model tight-binding calculations with the inclusion of spin–orbit coupling. The optimized geometry of the Ni3C12S12, shown in a, is a planar symmetric kagome–honeycomb framework, with Ni atoms placed at the kagome sites and the organic moieties at the honeycomb sites. The band structures, obtained with both PBE and HSE06 functionals, and with the inclusion of spin–orbit coupling, are shown in b and c, respectively. The figures show a strong qualitative and quantitative dependence of the band structure with the chosen functional, especially for the valence bands. The valence band maximum (VBM) in the PBE calculation is a dispersive band, while the VBM in the HSE06 calculation is a flat band (similar results were obtained for Ni3(HITP)2 ). The PBE functional predicts an indirect band gap of 85 meV for Ni3C12S12, while the HSE06 functional predicts an almost three times larger (230 meV) direct band gap at the Γ point. The spin–orbit induced band gap opening at the Dirac point between the first and second conduction bands is very similar for both functionals (14 meV). A band gap of about twice that value (30 meV) is opened at the K-point Dirac point below the Fermi energy for the HSE06 functional calculation, indicating a strong electron–hole asymmetry for the spin–orbit coupling at the Dirac points. The projection of the wave functions at the d orbitals of the Ni atoms calculated with both functionals show that there is no contribution of these orbitals for the VBM at the Γ point, which explains the absence of a gap induced due to spin–orbit coupling. Moreover, the projection calculated with HSE06 shows a much stronger contribution of the d orbitals for the Dirac point at the valence bands than the Dirac point at the conduction bands, explaining the asymmetry of the gap opening due to spin–orbit coupling effects.

elements.content: The rich spin–orbit coupling phenomenology for Ni3C12S12 described in the preceding paragraph, as well as the magnitude of those effects (up to a fourth of the band gap), indicates the importance of this interaction. Accordingly, we included in the model tight-binding Hamiltonian an intrinsic spin–orbit coupling term introduced by Kane and Mele, following Haldane H SO = ± i ∑ i j p i j c i † ( σ⃗ · v⃗ i j ) c j where p ij is the spin–orbit coupling strength, σ⃗ are the spin Pauli matrices, i and j connect second neighbors, and v⃗ ij = d⃗ kj × d⃗ ik represents the cross product between unit vectors along second neighbors i and j connected by the k site. This term was included in the tight-binding Hamiltonian following two different procedures. In the first procedure, which we call conventional procedure, the total Hamiltonian becomes H 0 + V + H SO, where H SO is the Kane–Mele intrinsic term described above, which in our tight-binding basis set is given by H SO = ± 2 i p ( 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 C 1 − C 2 0 0 − C 1 0 C 3 0 0 C 2 − C 3 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 ) where the C i have the same meaning as in (the same expression is obtained with the Hamiltonian proposed by Tang et al.).

elements.content: The conventional procedure described above is adequate in cases where all the atomic sites contribute equally to spin–orbit coupling. This is, however, not the case of the present Hamiltonians (both DFT and tight-binding) where only the metal site, with a large atomic number, is expected to contribute significantly to the intrinsic spin–orbit coupling. Accordingly, we propose here an alternative procedurewhich we call weighted procedureto include the Kane–Mele term in the tight-binding Hamiltonian. In this procedure, we define a weighted spin–orbit coupling Hamiltonian H WSO, in the basis set of the wavevectors {ψ} of H 0, as ⟨ ψ i | H WSO | ψ j ⟩ = ⟨ ψ i | H SO | ψ j ⟩ ⟨ ψ i | m ⟩ ⟨ m | ψ j ⟩ where ⟨m|ψ j ⟩ ≡ m j is the projection of |ψ j ⟩ on all metal sites. With ϵ i 0 (k⃗) being the eigenvalues of H 0, we have in this basis H i j ( k⃗ ) = δ i j ϵ i 0 ( k⃗ ) + ⟨ ψ i | H SO | ψ j ⟩ m i * ( k⃗ ) m j ( k⃗ ) which can now be diagonalized. For practical purposes, we can approximate m j as N ( m j ) where N(m j ) is the projected norm of the Kohn–Sham wave function at the metal sites as calculated through DFT.

elements.content: The effects of the inclusion of spin–orbit coupling in the tight-binding Hamiltonian following the two procedures described aboveconventional and weighted are shown in a and b, respectively. The set of tight-binding parameters used to obtain these fittings within the next nearest-neighbor hopping approximation is show in , where we set p = 0.028t. The conventional procedure results in an artifact at the valence band maximum, namely a splitting of the two highest valence bands near the Γ point. Such splitting is not observed in the DFT result. In contrast, the weighted spin–orbit Hamiltonian predicts correctly the absence of a gap in this point. This essentially originates from the absence of metal atom contribution near the Γ point of the VBM. Regarding the K point, the expanded views shown in a and b indicate that both spin–orbit procedures allow for a simultaneously good description of both Dirac point regions in the valence and the conduction bands, including the asymmetry in the band gap.

elements.content: In conclusion, the tight-binding single-orbital Hamiltonian model for a kagome–honeycomb lattice presented in this work is shown to reproduce the main features of the electronic structure of several 2D covalent–organic frameworks and metal–organic frameworks in a unified description. The model is fitted to single layers of Cu3(HITP)2, as well as to several examples of 2D covalent–organic frameworks, and is shown to achieve a quantitative agreement with first-principles calculations for the electronic structure of these systems, when hopping integrals up to second-neighbors couplings are taken into account. By tuning the parameters describing the hopping integrals and the band occupation, the model reproduces quantitatively the electronic structure of the five basic types of electronic structures displayed by these systems: metallic, graphene-like, gapped graphene, and semiconductor with a flat band degenerate with either of the band edges. Moreover, the model also provides a description of effects of crystallographic point group symmetry breaking on the opening of band gaps in specific 2D frameworks. Spin–orbit effects are also investigated in model and first-principles calculations of Ni3C12S12.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, the tight-binding single-orbital Hamiltonian model for a kagome-honeycomb lattice presented in this work is shown to reproduce the main features of the electronic structure of several 2D covalent-organic frameworks and metal-organic frameworks in a unified description. The model is fitted to single layers of Cu3(HITP)2, as well as to several examples of 2D covalent-organic frameworks, and is shown to achieve a quantitative agreement with first-principles calculations for the electronic structure of these systems, when hopping integrals up to second-neighbors couplings are taken into account. By tuning the parameters describing the hopping integrals and the band occupation, the model reproduces quantitatively the electronic structure of the five basic types of electronic structures displayed by these systems: metallic, graphene-like, gapped graphene, and semiconductor with a flat band degenerate with either of the band edges. Moreover, the model also provides a description of effects of crystallographic point group symmetry breaking on the opening of band gaps in specific 2D frameworks. Spin-orbit effects are also investigated in model and first-principles calculations of Ni3C12S12.

elements.content: As a final comment, we mention that a possible extension of the kagome–honeycomb lattice model proposed here is the inclusion of multiple orbitals per site with different symmetries and/or angular momenta. Such extension has been shown to be effective, for instance, when p x and p y orbitals are included in tight-binding calculations, as well as d orbitals.
